quiz.title: Unit 7: Labor Markets (Quiz 8)
quiz.subtitle: 7.8 The Role of Labor Unions: Collective Bargaining Impact (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Labor Unions, Collective Bargaining, Union Effects, Labor Relations

questions.question: The primary economic purpose of labor unions is to:
options: Increase wages and improve working conditions for members
questions.explanation: Unions primarily aim to improve compensation, benefits, and working conditions for their members through collective bargaining.

questions.question: Collective bargaining refers to:
options: Individual workers negotiating their own contracts
Unions negotiating with employers on behalf of all members
Government setting wages for all industries
Companies collaborating to set industry wages
questions.explanation: Collective bargaining is the process where unions negotiate wages, benefits, and working conditions with employers representing all union members.

questions.question: The union wage premium typically ranges between:
questions.explanation: Union workers typically earn 10-20% more than similar non-union workers, though this varies by industry, occupation, and country.

questions.question: A 'closed shop' requires that:
options: Workers must join the union after being hired
Workers must be union members before being hired
questions.explanation: In a closed shop, employers can only hire workers who are already union members, giving unions maximum control over labor supply.

questions.question: The 'union density' measures:
options: The percentage of workers who are union members
The number of unions in an economy
questions.explanation: Union density = (Union members รท Total workers) ร 100%, indicating the proportion of workers represented by unions.

questions.question: A strike occurs when:
questions.explanation: A strike is workers' collective refusal to work, used as bargaining leverage when negotiations break down.

questions.question: The 'spillover effect' of unions refers to how:
options: Union gains can affect non-union workers' wages
questions.explanation: The spillover effect occurs when non-union employers raise wages to avoid unionization or when laid-off union workers increase non-union labor supply.

questions.question: Unions typically reduce wage inequality by:
options: Increasing wages more for high-skilled workers
Compressing wage structures within unionized firms
questions.explanation: Unions often negotiate standardized pay scales that reduce wage dispersion within firms, particularly between high and low-skilled workers.

questions.question: The 'threat effect' occurs when:
options: Non-union firms raise wages to deter unionization
questions.explanation: The threat effect describes how non-union employers may increase wages and improve conditions to reduce the appeal of unionization to their workers.

questions.question: Right-to-work laws:
options: Require all workers to join unions
Prohibit requiring union membership as a condition of employment
questions.explanation: Right-to-work laws make union security agreements illegal, meaning workers cannot be required to join or pay dues to a union as a condition of employment.

questions.question: Unions can increase productivity through:
options: Reducing worker turnover and improving morale
questions.explanation: Unions may increase productivity by reducing turnover (saving hiring costs), improving worker morale, and establishing formal grievance procedures.

questions.question: The 'monopoly face' of unions refers to their ability to:
options: Restrict labor supply and increase wages
questions.explanation: The monopoly face describes unions' power to restrict labor supply and bargain for above-market wages, similar to how monopolists restrict output.

questions.question: Unions' political activities typically focus on:
questions.explanation: Unions engage in political advocacy for policies like higher minimum wages, stronger workplace safety regulations, and pro-union labor laws.

questions.question: The 'collective voice' function of unions refers to their role in:
options: Speaking for workers in political debates
questions.explanation: The collective voice function allows workers to communicate preferences to management through formal channels, potentially improving workplace efficiency.

questions.question: Unionization rates have generally _____ in most developed countries since the 1980s.
questions.explanation: Union density has declined in most developed countries due to structural economic changes, globalization, and policy shifts.

questions.question: Featherbedding refers to:
questions.explanation: Featherbedding is the union practice of requiring employers to hire more workers than needed or limit work output to create more jobs.

questions.question: Unions tend to have the strongest presence in:
questions.explanation: Unions have traditionally been strongest in manufacturing, construction, transportation, and public sector employment.

questions.question: The Wagner Act of 1935:
options: Established the right to collective bargaining in the US
questions.explanation: The Wagner Act (National Labor Relations Act) guaranteed workers' rights to organize and bargain collectively, establishing the National Labor Relations Board.

questions.question: Unions can create economic inefficiency by:
questions.explanation: When unions push wages above competitive levels, they can reduce employment and create deadweight loss, though they may also create offsetting benefits.

questions.question: The median voter model in union behavior suggests that unions:
options: Focus on preferences of the median union member
questions.explanation: The median voter model predicts unions will pursue policies favored by the median member, often leading to wage compression and seniority rules.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand the economic role of unions, collective bargaining, and their labor market impacts.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but should review union effects on wages, different union arrangements, and historical trends.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: how collective bargaining works, union wage effects, and the economic arguments for and against unions.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that unions aim to improve worker conditions through collective action, affecting wages, employment, and workplace practices.
